title: For India, Fading U.N. Status Could Be a Blessing in Disguise
text:
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi addresses the 2015 Sustainable Development Summit at the United Nations, New York, Sept. 25, 2015 (AP photo by Seth Wenig). For India, Fading U.N. Status Could Be a Blessing in Disguise Richard Gowan Monday, Oct. 12, 2015 
Does India still need the United Nations? Does the U.N. still need India? New Delhi and the New York-headquartered organization have always had a complex political relationship. India prides itself on having acted as a leading voice for the developing world at the U.N. in the era of decolonization. It remains a leading contributor of troops and police to blue-helmet peace operations. But there is little heartfelt warmth in the relationship these days.Indian officials have made very little progress toward their overarching goal at the U.N.: securing a permanent seat on the Security Council. New Delhi has been pressing this issue on and off for years, but made an extra push in 2015, to coincide with the U.N.’s 70th birthday. It would be unfair to say that they got nowhere at all, as diplomats hashed out a new document as the basis for negotiations on the matter. ... ×
